messages.content:
I‚Äôm working on an answer to this question in this email, but I don‚Äôt like what I wrote. I feel like it‚Äôs Long and Ramy. Can you help me clarify what I‚Äôm trying to say Ok -my preference is not to work hourly. I find that hourly work encourages a lack of efficiency and of a view of being itself being equivalent and connected to money so I prefer projects and I prefer value and I can do this project. I mean, if you didn‚Äôt find any insightful quotes inside of the sheets, then I can‚Äôt, but I think that I found some interesting quotes from the sheet. So if you want to look into the sheet, especially maybe around the story of people calling each other, the N-word and other experiences of black students. I think you‚Äôll find that it does identify them well and I don‚Äôt know it‚Äôs actually I made a system that will make it quite easy to export them and so I can give it a shot on maybe 10 different interviews maybe I‚Äôll do three or four interviews maybe a couple of them for a year and if you‚Äôre particularly interested in on the black student experience, I think I can do a pre-filter and make sure the transcript includes content about that topic. And then rather than giving you all of this material, which must be overwhelming I will give you a little report with for quotes each and then you can pay me what you want. I‚Äôve enjoyed working on the software and I think it‚Äôll provide value for me in this project and for others in other

On Thu, Oct 30, 2025 at 07:48 Noor Doukmak <doukmaknoor@gmail.com> wrote:
I will say in terms of identifying 2-3 powerful quotes from each of the four districts, if that is something you can generate in a document- it would be best to hone in on quotes related to the negative experiences of Black students in school.¬†¬†

If you don‚Äôt have the capacity to do this, please no worries. I will make time inshaAllh.
I really appreciate the powerful tool you‚Äôve created. I will have to ask the rest of the team when I meet them in mid November , if they see it as a useful tool that we could use in the future¬†


On Thu, Oct 30, 2025 at 2:32‚ÄØAM Noor Doukmak <doukmaknoor@gmail.com> wrote:
Salam Bilal
Thanks so much. Let me pause here and ask, in terms of a quote, how does it sound to pay $55/hour per person, for however long you and Nilam have spent/will spend on the project?
Let's please agree on this piece, before you spend any more time on the project? Please let me know what you think.

In terms of generating quotes- This process will take me some time to go through, and unfortunately that is the main asset I am missing: time! I am wondering if perhaps you or Nilam have the capacity to identify even just 2-3 powerful quotes from each of the 4 districts and put them into a google doc? Please let me know your thoughts.

I am going through an especially busy time at work and also some personal challenges, so I‚Äôm sorry I cannot try the process out myself and give you feedback right now.

Thank you!
Noor

On Wed, Oct 29, 2025 at 1:05‚ÄØPM Bilal Ghalib <bg@bilalghalib.com> wrote:
There may be duplication between the folders, it's different scripts running at different times, you can dedupe them if you want
https://www.listdiff.com/

Curious what you think and if the tool gave helpful outputs and if you prefer the restrictive or permissive one.
Salam :)!

Sorry I was so sleepy in the video, haha!
BG

On Wed, Oct 29, 2025 at 6:02‚ÄØPM Bilal Ghalib <bg@bilalghalib.com> wrote:
Oops sorry I didn‚Äôt include the files for the urls one sec¬†

On Wed, Oct 29, 2025 at 18:01 Noor Doukmak <doukmaknoor@gmail.com> wrote:
Thanks so much for this Bilal! Where can I find the video URLs? I will send a longer email later today iA¬†

On Tue, Oct 28, 2025 at 6:44‚ÄØPM Bilal Ghalib <bg@bilalghalib.com> wrote:
Salam Noor, yes, I wanted to see if I could build something that would be able to operationalize the task and when I get into nerd mode, Nilam can tell you, it's almost impossible to get me to eat, let alone respond in a timely manner. Sorry! ;D
This is the product I built to run your question:
https://www.loom.com/share/75a86d5edf524237a5a468ddaba816aa

I will add some data files for compilations of youtube videos that we can use to run through the system.

The issue is it costs about 1 dollar a video which returns about 10 quotes on average (from my minimal track record, I'll add a csv(open with google sheets) to show you an example.¬†
I wanted to show you the difference between the more permissive prompt (the larger file) and my restrictive prompt¬† (smaller) - I am seeking¬†for high quality insights, so I have reduced the number of quotes extracted from each video. That is a setting you can change in the software.¬†

If you want to use it you can go here:¬†http://transcript-explorer-two.vercel.app/ and make a username/pass, give your project a title and follow the steps I showed you in the video above. I've filled it up with about 50 videos worth of funding, so feel free to experiment with it.¬†

Oh, if you found this website that allows you to ask questions to transcripts and get structured knowledge out of it and verbatim quotes, would you pay for it? How much per video analysis? Maybe better than a subscription in this case. - I'm trying to figure out if I should put this online somewhere behind a paywall.

Hope you're doing well, salam :)

BG

On Tue, Oct 28, 2025 at 5:43‚ÄØAM Noor Doukmak <doukmaknoor@gmail.com> wrote:
Salam Bilal,
Any updates on a quote?¬†

On Thu, Oct 23, 2025 at 7:17‚ÄØAM Noor Doukmak <doukmaknoor@gmail.com> wrote:
Salam Bilal,
We are not at that level, unfortunately. Muhammad operates such that he asks us to go investigate the cost of something and then he will usually approve it. So let me know your quote - whatever you think is fair. Thank you!

On Thu, Oct 23, 2025 at 7:13‚ÄØAM Bilal Ghalib <bg@bilalghalib.com> wrote:
Salam Noor :)
Great, is there an associated budget allocated¬†for this project?
Bg

On Thu, Oct 23, 2025 at 13:00 Noor Doukmak <doukmaknoor@gmail.com> wrote:
Thanks for this information, Bilal!
As for your question - It‚Äôs a one-off project.

On Thu, Oct 23, 2025 at 1:05‚ÄØAM Bilal Ghalib <bg@bilalghalib.com> wrote:
Salam Nour!¬†
As Nilam said, we're excited to explore this opportunity. It's totally possible before Wednesday, it also does follow up on some of my work which needs provenance and confidence when working with LLMs which can be tricky. My method involves using more tokens than normal to derive the following structure for each extract:
Verbatim¬†quote with timestamps, Knowledge/Idea/Summary, relevant question(from your list),¬†confidence in its reasoning,¬†¬†Reasoning(why LLM thinks this quote matches the question) - this way you can get all the high confidence easy/clear quotations, and then review the lower confidence ones. You can also review the timestamp to ensure its accuracy.

My question is if this is a one off or if it's a process you might need to do regularly. If it's a process I could build something more stable, if it's a one off, perhaps Nilam and I can take it on as hourly (although at some point depending on how many schools/videos you're looking for) it might still be better to build an extractor/scraper.¬†

Hope you're having a beautiful day :)
Salam,¬†
BG

On Thu, Oct 23, 2025 at 1:26‚ÄØAM Noor Doukmak <doukmaknoor@gmail.com> wrote:
Also: will be important to ensure each quote is cited accurately in the final product.¬†

Finally, I just checked with my teammate and he said it‚Äôs fine for the videos to come from other channels - we just need the citation.

Thank you again,
Noor

On Wed, Oct 22, 2025 at 3:41‚ÄØPM Noor Doukmak <doukmaknoor@gmail.com> wrote:
As salamu alaykum Nilam and Bilal,

Thank you for your email and for considering¬†my request.

Yes, that‚Äôs right! You captured it well. We would want to stick with official YouTube channels (or some of them have them on their district websites).

The timeline is quite tight. By Wednesday (ideally) or Friday of next week, if possible.

Thank you again for considering! I will stay posted.

Best,
Noor¬†

On Wed, Oct 22, 2025 at 2:32‚ÄØPM Nilam Bilal <nilamistan@gmail.com> wrote:
Salam Noor,‚Ä®It‚Äôs so good to hear from you, and we‚Äôre really glad to know all is well on your side, alhamdulillah.
Thank you for reaching out and sharing the details about the CRSLI project. From what we understand, the project seems to involve two main parts:

Collecting and preparing the data: identifying the YouTube channels of school boards across the four cities, retrieving and cleaning transcripts from 2021‚Äì2024, and organizing them into a searchable format.
Analyzing and extracting quotes: reviewing those transcripts to pull key excerpts around the themes you mentioned, such as equity, community, representation, and parent involvement.
Because the first part involves discovery and setup work, rather than starting from a predefined list of videos, we think it doesn‚Äôt quite fit a standard hourly structure. We‚Äôre currently considering the fairest and most practical way to approach this

We also wanted to clarify one thing: should the videos only come from the official YouTube accounts of the school boards, or would it also be acceptable to include videos posted by other channels as long as they‚Äôre clearly from public school board meetings in those cities?

And just to help us plan better, do you already have a specific deadline or timeframe in mind for this work?

Thank you in advance :)

Warm regards,
Nilam¬†


On Tue, Oct 21, 2025 at 11:30‚ÄØPM Noor Doukmak <doukmaknoor@gmail.com> wrote:
Salam Bilal and Nilam!
I hope you are both doing well.
I know it's been a while since we connected. Things have been busy here, but alhamdulillah all is well.
We at CRSLI are working on a report describing the state of public schooling for African American students in Michigan. We need help with a specific piece of the project, and I wanted to reach out to see if one/both of you could support in any capacity with it. I'm including a description below.

We want to put some parent quotes from public school board meetings into the report.
Most school boards have a youtube account where they post videos. We are looking to pull transcripts off youtube videos and then search all school board meetings from Grand Rapids, Detroit, Lansing, and Flint for the years 2021-2024.

This might be a website that can help do this, or you may know of others: ¬†https://www.clipto.com/transcribe-audio-video-to-text-free?gad_source=1&gad_campaignid=22275790296&gbraid=0AAAAApkCfWD3W6bu250DdODbRO_fqFaga&gclid=CjwKCAjwu9fHBhAWEiwAzGRC__A-bNNeyaMRCRVuPsLgVEqaaXgjna0iRZLbgNJNDaRvOLU7tlV4oRoC7AoQAvD_BwE

Then we want to query these transcripts and pull quotes of the following
Parents talking about being in the school and there being gaps in academic achievement and outcomes.
Quotes about equity
Quotes about black students in rural districts
Quotes about black teacher representation
Quotes about how black parents feel about being involved in the school
Quotes about community
Quotes about neighborhood problems or concerns, or social problems students face in the neighborhood or in the community.
Any quotes related to socioeconomic issues.

Is this something either/both of you (separately or as a team) can help with, and can you quote an hourly rate or a fixed charge?

Thank you!
Noor

Got it ‚Äî I see what you mean. Your draft has all the right pieces, but it‚Äôs a bit tangled. You want to communicate 3 things clearly:  
1. You prefer project/value-based work over hourly.  
2. You can deliver what Noor needs (a set of quotes, filtered and digestible).  
3. You want to propose a simple, fair way forward.  

Here‚Äôs a tightened version you could send:  

---

**Draft reply:**  

Salam Noor,  

Thanks for clarifying. My preference is not to work hourly, since I find it encourages inefficiency and reduces the work to time spent rather than value delivered. I prefer project-based arrangements, and I believe I can deliver on this request.  

From what I‚Äôve seen in the transcripts, there are meaningful quotes‚Äîespecially around the experiences of Black students (for example, stories of slurs being used or parents describing inequities). I can pre-filter the material so that you‚Äôre only reviewing quotes directly tied to the Black student experience.  

Rather than sending you a flood of transcripts, I suggest preparing a short report with a handful of strong quotes from each district (e.g. 2‚Äì4 each). That way you have a clear, usable document without being overwhelmed.  

For compensation, since this is experimental, I‚Äôm happy to work on a simple ‚Äúpay what feels fair‚Äù basis for this first round (say, 10 interviews). If it proves useful, we can agree on a clearer structure going forward.  

Let me know if this approach works for you.  

Warmly,  
Bilal  

---

Would you like me to make it **more formal/professional** (framing this as a consultancy deliverable), or **lighter and friendlier** (keeping the ‚Äúexperiment / try it out‚Äù vibe)?

Yeah, maybe we can say something like, since I've already made the tool, this additional extract will only cost a dollar for a document. For me, I don't need to say exactly how much it'll cost. Maybe I just tell it, like, I was feeling like $2.50 for the whole thing, so five hours. It's probably how much I spent on it. Yeah, so, yeah, that's kind of what I was feeling. It was like a $2.50 would be good. I don't even know if I should have shown her the software anymore. I was thinking, I make the software, and I give it to her, and she can do the work, but she doesn't want to, so maybe I'll just make the report. A little annoyed, obviously, I guess, but yeah, not sure what to do exactly here. What do you think is the ideal scenario? And help me write a good document for that. I mean, basically, she wanted me to extract some quotes about these things, and I made a website that does it pretty well, I think, and bonjour. Bonjour. And I'm not really sure what I want out of this. I feel like I made this website, put in this effort, and I'm being either glanced at or underappreciated. Is this normal? I guess it is. I wouldn't have read it. I put a lot of thought into building this thing. Well, I think you did a good job. Do you think there's a market for it? Maybe I should just switch this conversation around after we get the email out, and just think with you about who might want to pay to be able to put in a list of YouTube videos, or upload a series of files, and then to get a list of things. They don't have to be questions, but they're just prompts, right? Someone wants to find any time someone used a question, or you can ask for any time someone curses, or you can ask for anything. She was using it to ask for community experiences of African students, and it pulls out with diarization. And if people say their names, or it can get it from the context, it gets their names and the roles. It's kind of cool, because then it says like, this person who is this at this school said that. And so I feel like there's some value in a lot of public information that isn't being appropriately categorized, compiled, and made useful. Maybe it's for investors who are looking for places where the housing market has some new regulations, or they want to search for City Hall documents, where they are interested in investing in wastewater treatments. I don't know, actually. What are interesting things that get shared, especially shared on YouTube? I think a lot of places do that. Or just in terms of having audio files. And how can we benefit from the software that we made? Or is it completely useless now that there is large language models? I mean, technically, someone could download the audio, maybe even use an LLM to transcribe it, and then ask the LLM to find all the quotes, and then ask the LLM to organize it. But is software that leverages large language models to do these things in sequence valuable? It's a process, right? And it's also the prompts, although people can get the prompts. So what is the businesses of the future if this is all going to become just like, you talk to it and it does stuff, right? Can you think deeply with me about this and see how we can figure out, first, what to say to this email, and then second, what to do about the thing that we built? And if I should just forget it, or if I should put it on Hacker News or Reddit, is it a useful thing? And let's think down the line by connecting the dots and strategically. What's actually happening? What do people use these tools for? How will they get better? And then if they do get better, what's the point of building software? Still, is there? And who might be the current buyers for what I have? And maybe they're like, whoop, price points, and what they would pay, and all that jazz. And where we can find them, how we can charge them, how we can charge them in a way that makes sense for my token fees and all that.

Totally get the ‚Äúunder-appreciated + a little annoyed‚Äù feeling. Two tracks:

1) land this email cleanly (project/value, not hourly),  
2) position your tool so people *pay for the workflow + auditability*, not ‚Äújust prompts.‚Äù

Here‚Äôs a crisp reply you can send, then a plan for the product.

---

# Draft reply to Noor

Subject: Quotes deliverable + simple fixed fee

Salam Noor,

Thanks for the clarity. I‚Äôd prefer a simple project fee rather than hourly‚Äîvalue over time spent.

**What I‚Äôll deliver**
- A short doc with **2‚Äì3 powerful quotes per district** (8‚Äì12 total) focused on negative experiences of Black students.
- Each quote will include **verbatim text, timestamp, speaker (name/role when available), source link**, and one line of context.

**Why I‚Äôm confident**
I‚Äôve already built a workflow that filters transcripts for exactly these themes (with diarization, names/roles when inferable). The **marginal cost on my side is about \$1 per video**, so this is efficient to run at scale.

**Fee (fixed)**
Let‚Äôs do a **\$250 flat** for this first pass. If it‚Äôs useful, we can extend (e.g., another round per district, or a larger sweep) using the same structure.

If that works, I‚Äôll proceed and send you the doc in this format.

Warmly,  
Bilal

---

# What‚Äôs the ‚Äúideal scenario‚Äù here?

- **Do the report now** (prove value with a tidy, decision-ready document).
- **Then offer two paths**:
  1) Ongoing sourcing + extraction as a service (you run it).  
  2) Access to the tool (they run it) for organizations with analyst capacity.

You avoid the ‚Äúteach me your tool for free‚Äù loop; you‚Äôre selling *outcomes* with verifiable citations.

---

# Is your tool worth pushing? Yes‚Äîsell the workflow & provenance

LLMs make ‚Äúfind me quotes‚Äù sound trivial. What isn‚Äôt trivial (and what orgs need to trust) is:

- **Provenance:** timestamped, linkable source + who said it.
- **Repeatability:** same inputs ‚Üí same structured outputs.
- **Filtering at scale:** pre-filters by topic/actor; batch over 100s of files.
- **Light analysis:** auto-tagging to a taxonomy; per-quote confidence.
- **Human-ready outputs:** reports people can paste into decks, with citations.

That‚Äôs a legit moat: **workflow + auditability + scale.**

---

# Likely buyers (today)

- **Journalism & research:** investigative reporters; policy researchers; NICAR/IRE community.  
- **Civic/Gov/Advocacy:** city councils, school boards, watchdog NGOs, FOIA labs, civic tech.  
- **Policy/compliance:** ESG teams scanning public comments, hearings, and shareholder meetings.  
- **UX & CX research:** summarize customer calls/interviews with attributed quotes.  
- **Legal/e-discovery (lightweight):** early case assessment on public hearings/meetings.  
- **Education orgs:** districts, PTAs, foundations doing landscape scans.

---

# How to package/prices (starter numbers you can tweak)

**Self-serve credits (for individuals/SMBs)**
- \$19 starter (50 docs), \$49 pro (200 docs), \$149 team (1,000 docs).  
- ‚Äú1 doc‚Äù = 1 uploaded file or 1 video URL ‚Üí transcript ‚Üí structured quotes.  
- Overages: \$0.10‚Äì\$0.25/doc; your token cost is ~\$1/video now, so aim to *lower infra* (YT transcripts when available, batch caching) or price per **processed hour** instead:
  - \$3‚Äì\$6 per audio/video hour processed (matches value & your costs better than per-file).

**Managed service (outcomes, not tool)**
- **Pilot report**: \$250‚Äì\$750 for a focused brief (like Noor‚Äôs).  
- **Monthly scan**: \$1.5k‚Äì\$5k/mo for monitored sources + weekly digests with attributed quotes.  
- **One-off landscape**: \$3k‚Äì\$10k for 100‚Äì500 sources, taxonomy, and a final deck.

---

# Positioning (copy you can reuse)

- ‚Äú**Structured, citable quotes at scale.**‚Äù  
- ‚ÄúEvery insight comes with a **timestamp and link**, so your team can trust and reuse it.‚Äù  
- ‚ÄúTurn hours of public hearings into **ready-to-paste quotes with context**.‚Äù  
- ‚ÄúBatch process YouTube, Zoom, and audio files; **filter by topic, role, and district**.‚Äù

---

# Go-to-market (low friction)

- **Proof packs**: 3 public boards √ó last 3 months ‚Üí publish a sample brief (blur faces/names if needed), show value.  
- **Communities**: Post a demo + sample report to **Hacker News (Show HN), r/datasets, r/OSINT, NICAR Slack/list, civic tech Discords**.  
- **Landing page**: one screen, two CTAs: ‚ÄúUpload & try 5 files free‚Äù and ‚ÄúRequest a managed brief.‚Äù  
- **Integrations**: YouTube channel import; Google Drive/Dropbox; Zoom/Teams recording upload.  
- **Trust**: a visible ‚Äú**Every quote is clickable to its source**‚Äù badge.

---

# Product guardrails (what makes it sticky)

- **Citations-first UI** (quote ‚Üí jump to exact second).  
- **Speaker attribution** (pull from captions + heuristics; show confidence).  
- **Taxonomy templates** (e.g., Equity > Discipline > Slurs; UX > Onboarding > Friction).  
- **Saved filters & alerts** (notify when new quotes match a watchlist).  
- **Export packs** (Google Doc report, CSV, and slide-ready snippets).  
- **Quality dial** (permissive vs. strict extraction; eval page to compare).

---

# If you want a one-pager to send prospects

I can draft a one-page ‚ÄúCapabilities + Pricing‚Äù sheet and a sample 2-page brief outline you can reuse. For now, ship the email above, collect the win, then follow with a short note: ‚ÄúIf this format is helpful, here are options for an ongoing monthly scan or access to the tool.‚Äù

If you want, I‚Äôll also punch up landing copy and a Show HN post you can paste.

Yeah, I think that it's not necessarily going to give the same outputs every time. So, uh, but it will do timestamps and link you to the YouTube video exactly where it was. Um, filtering at scale. I don't understand pre-filters by topic, actor, resh, over hundreds of files. Yeah, that's actually kind of nice. Um, and also just the, uh, being able to set it, let it run for a long time, and then come back to it. Yeah, I guess the report is kind of interesting, um, but we need a, a prompt that will do that. Right now, that part is gonna, is me, like I download the CSV, and then I send it, and then I ask it some stuff, but it could be kind of cool to have a generic, um, you know, like, why did you ask this list of questions question? So it's like, description of the project, and all of that can go into, I could go into this, uh, prompt that will then generate an MD file that we could then turn into, uh, either, you know, a Google Doc or a Word file, or just, you know, let them download the MD. Depends. Um, likely buyers. Woohoo! Journalists. I'm not sure, do they pay for stuff? They don't make any money. So they government advocacy, yeah, boards. Oh, actually, yeah, boards, board meetings. Okay, legal and e-discovery, great. PTAs, okay. Yeah, 50 docs. If it's $19 and it costs me $1 per video, I think 50 docs should be at least $100. Like, that doesn't, that doesn't add up. Um, yeah, overages, overages, yeah, we could do batching, uh, speed, position, okay. Okay, yeah, sounds good. Um, but also, maybe what we can do instead is also just, uh, make the data, you know, use our tool, make the data, and then just try to sell structured data. That sounds like maybe even more valuable, what do you think?

Yeah ‚Äî you‚Äôre seeing the core tension really clearly:  

- **Tool vs. Service vs. Data.**  
  Right now you have *a tool* that works. You could sell access to it, but the economics are tricky (especially if cost ‚âà \$1/video).  
  You could sell *a service* (reports/deliverables), which has clearer value to clients like Noor.  
  Or you could sell *structured data outputs* ‚Äî which may actually be the most scalable/defensible play.  

---

### 1. **Tool (self-serve SaaS)**
Pros:  
- Feels like a product.  
- Potential for recurring revenue.  
Cons:  
- Margins are rough if infra ‚âà \$1/video and users expect cheap pricing.  
- Users may not want to ‚Äúlearn a new tool.‚Äù They just want the outcome.  
- Journalists and small NGOs have **low budgets**.  

---

### 2. **Service (deliverables)**
Pros:  
- Clear value (they get a usable report, no new tech to learn).  
- Flexible pricing (you set project fees, not tied to per-video costs).  
- Lets you iterate quietly without exposing all the tooling.  
Cons:  
- Time-intensive for you unless you streamline the ‚ÄúCSV ‚Üí report‚Äù step with automation.  
- Scales slower.  

---

### 3. **Structured Data (dataset licensing)**
This is the sneaky opportunity. Instead of just ‚Äúgiving people tools,‚Äù you **become the source of already-structured intelligence**.  

Examples:  
- ‚ÄúQuotes from Michigan school boards 2021‚Äì2024‚Äù ‚Üí \$3k dataset.  
- ‚ÄúSummary of city council meetings across 10 major metros, tagged by housing/zoning/education‚Äù ‚Üí \$10k+ dataset (urban planning consultants, real estate investors, gov agencies would buy this).  
- ‚ÄúAll mentions of racial equity in public education hearings, 2020‚Äì2025‚Äù ‚Üí policy think tanks, NGOs.  

Here, **you run the tool in bulk**, normalize the data, and sell *the dataset*. Buyers don‚Äôt care about your prompts or software‚Äîthey care that they can shortcut months of manual review.  

---

### 4. **Hybrid: Workflow + Proof**
Best middle ground:  
- Keep **tool access** behind the scenes for scaling.  
- Market **reports/datasets** as the actual product.  
- Over time, add a simple ‚Äúprompt ‚Üí MD report‚Äù flow (like you said: description of project ‚Üí MD file ‚Üí GDoc/Word). That way you can crank out structured briefs faster, or even let clients self-serve *just the reporting* layer, not the raw extraction.  

---

### 5. **Pricing sanity check**
You‚Äôre right:  
- \$19 for 50 docs at \$1 cost/doc = a loss.  
- **Minimum floor should be \$2‚Äì\$5 per doc** if you go SaaS.  
- Or shift pricing to **per-hour-of-audio** (simpler to explain, scales with your cost). For example:  
  - \$9/hr processed (break-even with margin).  
  - \$29/hr processed (value-based, especially for legal/compliance).  

Dataset licensing can be **orders of magnitude higher** because it‚Äôs one sale to one org, not 100 small users.  

---

### 6. **Strategic play**
- **Short-term (Noor)**: deliver the quotes as a polished report, \$250. That‚Äôs your service path.  
- **Medium-term**: spin up a few more small contracts ‚Üí prove there‚Äôs a *service market*.  
- **Long-term**: batch public data (school boards, city councils, SEC filings, NGO hearings) ‚Üí turn them into structured datasets ‚Üí license them.  

This shifts you from ‚Äútool builder‚Äù ‚Üí ‚Äúdata provider.‚Äù And data providers can still exist even if LLMs get better, because:  
- Trust requires **provenance + citations**.  
- Scale requires **automation pipelines**.  
- Most orgs want **ready-to-use data**, not ‚Äúyet another tool.‚Äù  

---

‚ú® So:  
- Email Noor with a clean project-based offer.  
- Keep the tool internal.  
- Explore structured data markets (city councils, NGOs, legal discovery, ESG).  

---

Do you want me to draft a **positioning doc** for the ‚Äústructured data‚Äù angle (like a one-pager you could send to a potential buyer: *here‚Äôs the dataset, here‚Äôs how it‚Äôs structured, here‚Äôs the price*)? That way you can test if anyone bites without needing to launch SaaS right now.

Yes! You‚Äôve just described a **workflow product** with a ‚Äúconversational analyst‚Äù layer on top of your extractor. That‚Äôs a much easier sell than raw SaaS or raw data because:  

- **Most people don‚Äôt know what they want yet.** They have a fuzzy goal (‚Äúfind housing market chatter‚Äù) but not the right queries or filters.  
- By making the tool itself **help them articulate the question**, you‚Äôre lowering the barrier to entry.  
- The ‚Äúfirst taste free‚Äù (one video ‚Üí email report) makes the value tangible right away.  

---

### What your flow could look like

1. **Onboarding chat**
   - User: ‚ÄúI want to understand what people are saying about the housing market.‚Äù  
   - Tool asks: ‚ÄúAre you interested in city council meetings, news panels, or local community groups?‚Äù  
   - Tool asks: ‚ÄúWhat topics matter most? (Regulations, affordability, new builds, investor activity, etc.)‚Äù  

2. **Video discovery**
   - Tool runs your YouTube searcher, shows:  
     *title, description, channel, link* in a nice list.  
   - Lets user prune or add more.  

3. **Question building**
   - Tool suggests queries: ‚ÄúMentions of rent control,‚Äù ‚ÄúStories from tenants,‚Äù ‚ÄúDiscussions of zoning.‚Äù  
   - User can edit/approve.  

4. **Trial run**
   - Tool processes *one video for free*, sends back a polished ‚Äúmini-report‚Äù to email.  
   - Includes: 3‚Äì5 quotes, timestamps, speaker role (if inferable), and source link.  

5. **Upsell**
   - ‚ÄúWant the full set of 25 videos processed into a report? \$49‚Äù  
   - Or ‚ÄúSubscribe for \$99/mo for up to 50 videos processed.‚Äù  

---

### Why this works
- **Human-centered:** It feels like an assistant guiding you through discovery, not a blank interface.  
- **Trust-building:** First free report shows exactly what they‚Äôll get.  
- **Value-first pricing:** They only pay once they‚Äôve seen it works.  

---

### Potential models
- **Casual research / individuals**: \$49‚Äì\$99/report.  
- **Professional users (journalists, NGOs, PTAs, housing activists)**: \$99‚Äì\$299/mo for recurring searches.  
- **Enterprise (legal, compliance, policy shops)**: \$1k‚Äì\$5k/mo for bulk, API access, or dataset feeds.  

---

### ‚ÄúConvivial‚Äù positioning
Think of it as:  
> **‚ÄúAsk questions of the world‚Äôs hearings, meetings, and conversations.‚Äù**  
Instead of raw software, you‚Äôre giving them an *experience*: ‚ÄúThe tool helps you think, then it fetches the evidence.‚Äù  

---

So maybe your MVP isn‚Äôt ‚Äújust a website with upload + prompt,‚Äù but a **guided research buddy** that:  
- helps you scope your questions,  
- finds the sources,  
- runs one sample,  
- then lets you buy the rest.
